Early Access Review

** Key was provided by developer for review purposes	**
*This review is of the 6.4 version of the game*
I used a controller and keyboard to play through this game

Zombie Party
Zombie Party is a very fast-paced 2D bullet hell game where you fight zombies, demons, ice shards, and even pyramids. Currently the game is in early access but it seems to be going in a good direction. I will add a TL;DR at the end.

Gameplay
In Zombie party there are currently three game modes to try which include Adventure, Survival, and a Dungeon Beta. In Adventure mode you start at a forest stage after choosing your character and kill everything plus one boss to advance to the next zone and so on. In Survival you select a zone and you fight in it as more and more enemies spawn and you have to try and survive (you do not advance to other zones). In the Dungeon Beta you fight through a dungeon and try to find the exit of the floor you are currently on as you go through chests and fight the enemies in your way. The fun of getting a super weapon in either of these game modes is amazing, you can get a turret launcher, rainbow gun, coin launcher, flamethrower etc. Definitely a good game to play if your bored or just willing to tear through enemies and then die to one stupid zombie... Anyway the overall gameplay is highly enjoyable and good to pass the time.

Features
Zombie Party has some fun features to behold such as:
- 16 characters to play
- Tons of guns
- Relics and upgrades which can be applied to your 5 base weapons
- Magical runes to crush your enemies with
- A upgrade system for individual characters and skill points
- A shop during games where you can change your 5 basic guns and buy health, relics, and runes
- Controller Support
- Multiple zones and super weapons
- Hats
- Destructible environments
- Different enemies and interesting bosses
- RPG system
- Local co-op

And more to come

Graphics/Sound
The graphics and sounds are very retro like and I'd say that's part of this games charm. The music matches very well with the style and helps set you right into the game. My personal favorite enemy to behold is the pyramid boss.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ Addictive
+ Fun with both keyboard and controller
+ Many features
+ Music
+ Easy to get into and good replay value
+ RPG type system

Cons
**Note that since this game is currently in early access that most of these issues will be fixed when the game is done**

- Controller buttons showing when using keyboard
- Bit slow at moments
- No explanation at beginning regarding what your doing, the different guns, the system, relics, and the enemies

Suggestions
These are my personal suggestions to the game that I feel will change the game for the better. (If already listed in planned features it will not be shown here)

- An encyclopedia for enemies, guns, relics, and runes.
- Themed Characters

Final Thoughts
I really enjoyed this game and cannot wait for online multiplayer to be a feature. This game is very well done so far and  I look forward to playing it's final copy. This game just appealed to me with almost everything  and I'm happy to have reviewed it.

TL;DR
Zombie Party is a 2D pixelated bullet hell game where you fight skeletons, zombies, demons, etc. You get to choose from 16 characters to play Adventure, Survival, or the Dungeon Beta. There are 5 basic weapons plus a lot more. You also use magic alongside your armory to fight off the huge waves of enemies and fight off bosses. I'd say this game is very fast-paced and easy to get into. The game is very well done so far and If you like the trailer of the game or games similar to it I would suggest checking Zombie Party out as it was highly enjoyable in my time playing it. Just in case you can check the features list to see if anything has been added since the time of this review.

As of May 19th 2016, I recommend. Lots of replay value.

Zombie Party over all was a nice bullet chaos with RPG elements and chaos as a middle name. And you can you will be able to share it with your friends! There are more weapons and extra abilities than you can wrap your head around. There are 4 game modes (Adventure, Dungeon, Arcade & Deathmatch) so its your choice what you feel like. Set your pace with Dungeon mode or if you want a chaos filled flying bullet nightmare check out the other three modes. Plenty of entertainment if this is your flavor of game.

My opinions here are spent on Dungeon and Adventure mode as Arcade felt impossible alone. Out of maybe 10 tries my best was 2,000 of the 10,000 kills needed to advance. When I tried Deathmatch it was a blast but it was so busy I didn't even know which person was me most of the time ːDː

Like:  Weapon selection is insane and you also get Mods. You start with a basic Pistol, SMG, shotgun, Assault Rifle, and a Launcher. When you use the shop in Dungeon & Adventure mode you will find there are several upgrade options to choose from. Your only limit is purchase cost. Then you can put up to 3 weapon mods on all the weapons and 1 artifact on all put the Pistol. I suspect cause its endless ammo. But a pistol with +dmg, ricochet and spread was absolutely insane in Dungeon. Another beautiful thing is that you can swap them at any time among all your weapons.

Quick Slots & extra abilities are given as melee weapons, ranged magic runes, potions or even explosives. You can hold up to three at a time and easily switch between them by pressing Q. These items can be obtained in chests or from killing monsters but they add so much more to the game. It feels like an endless possibility of various effects and stats.

Selling things is important. I can't express the joy that emptying my inventory of unwanted goods is as simple as right click unwanted item, anywhere, anytime.

Destruction! You can destroy everything on the map. ːDː I had much satisfaction with grenades, bomb & proximity mines loaded up in my Quick Slots in Dungeon mode. But not enough patience to try and level an entire floor.
Dislike:  While in Dungeon mode...what is this thing that never misses, leaves a giant hole and has happened 4 times on a single floor!? Im not a fan. I can't even tell if its a projectile coming off a mob, the sky, the ground...should be able to see and counter or dodge this.

Also progress resets in Dungeon & Adventure are a huge put off. I feel like there should be some kind of check point or save to make this more worthwhile. Could even be x gold to continue since it seems its currently only used in this Pet Sanctuary. But starting over at the very beginning is just antagonizing to me. And while still fun to get some shoot em up action...replaying the same beginning 20+ times does become kind of blah.

Currency feels like it could use a boost. In general feels slow and a little frustrating. I feel like the best bet to currency is selling drops. Since the drops are completely random (might get some, might not) frustration comes into play cause you need to buy HP but haven't gotten drops to do so.

I think this game would be oodles of fun with friends. Unfortunately multiplayer is very displeasing at this time. The MP was introduced in March from the news announcements, but has a beta disclaimer next to it in game, so a work in progress.

As of May 18th my experiences have been being booted with 'Couldn't connect to server, Try again' after already being in the game. Either walking in place, or skipping across the map. Also being told that im picking up items that I still see on the ground. Loaded one game and the grass texture did not appear to finish loading. And in the join delay I died 5 before I even knew what was going on.
Here's a screenshot of the death screen seconds after I joined.
http://i.imgur.com/D8E4hGR.jpg

Date: May 19, 2016
Rating: 9/10 only because the multiplayer still has some hiccups and I feel like this would be much more fun with friends than alone.

Zombie Party is an enjoyable and carnage filled Rogue-lite Action Arcade and Action-RPG game, via the different 4 modes available. You can tell that they put a lot of effort into the mechanics, with the RPG and Dungeon modes. Both are unique and have lots of variety to keep the game interesting.

There are a lot of bosses and extensive challenges that makes this game have a ton of replayability. It progressively gets harder in the waves you encounter in the RPG mode. The Dungeon mode is neat in that it gives you more of a dungeon crawl, so it's a little slower than the standard action or rpg modes.

Overall you can really get a lot out of this game with the amount on content already included. With the total carnage and an unending wave of enemies to destroy, you really get a lot of content and neverending arcade action. The game definitely has a lot going for it and I hope that it gets fine-tuned some more down the road. My only gripes is that a lot of the color from the background and foreground seem to get melded together as the action gets crazy, causing you to lose vision of the prospective horde of zombies and particles to avoid. Also the multiplayer still needs more work.

If you love insane action games with some rogue-lite and rpg-lite style gameplay, then this game is for you!

DISCLAIMER: Peach Pie Productions has provided me a key to try out this game. My review, however, is not affected by this action and will rate this game accordingly.
REVIEW

Zombie Party is a rogue-like game with a nice touch of RPG elements. This game honestly caught me by surprise. I thought I’ll be trying it for a couple of rounds, close the game and then write a review. But no, instead I tried all kinds of modes and try to get a higher score on the leader boards. The game is easy and it’s addicting. Every death just makes you want to do a better job on the next one.

Even though it was stated from start that this game is still in early access alpha stage, I honestly feel that this game is close to being a complete game.

PROS
Character Selection – No single character is the same as the previous one, each has their own different stats and starting weapons. There are few characters that are recognizable to most like Agent 48, Jason, Daft Punk, Robin Hood, and more.
Weapon Variation – With over 150 weapons to choose from, ranging from a generic firearms like handgun to unique weapons shooting rainbows. This game will surely satisfy you.
Weapon Modifications – You can add up to three different runes to your weapons such as piercing, additional damage, spread shots and many more. Not only runes, but you can also add artefacts that could burn your enemies on hit or poison them.
Enemies/Bosses/Maps – Each map has its own set of enemies and a final boss. With this, it won’t be easily become repetitive as most rogue-like game does.
CONS
Checkpoints – There are none. Whether you’re in a Dungeon or Adventure mode, once you die, you’ll have to restart again. I know this is a rogue-like game, but maybe atleast give us an option for that? It’s already bad enough that you have to start at the same map, with the same enemies each time you start.
Frame Rate Drops – For a game with this kind of graphics, even with the number of projectiles coming at you, I didn’t expect to experience some fps drops.

Early Access Review

Zombie Party is a “rogue like” action-RPG that is simple in nature but surprisingly fun and addicting. There are several game modes available, tons of weapons and upgrades, plenty of different enemies (NOT just zombies), procedurally generated destructible environments, single-player and multi-player (both online and local).

Game modes:
Adventure

“A time traveling RPG adventure”. You face 5 waves of enemies with increasing difficulty and a boss fight after that. There is a quick break after each wave when you can buy/sell items, weapons & upgrade your character. Once the boss is dead you teleport to a new world. This mode is equally fun in single-player as well as co-op.

Dungeon

“A dungeon-crawling rogue-like experience”. Pretty similar to “Adventure”: 5 dungeon levels end with a boss fight. The main difference is that you don’t have to kill all the enemies, you just need to find an entrance to the next level. Although killing everyone and collecting all the loot helps you progress faster and you will definitely need it as it only gets harder the lower you go. Some of the dungeons are quite tight with plenty of narrow passages which makes fighting more challenging. For the same reason I prefer to play this mode solo.

Arcade

“Try to kill 10,000 zombies in 5 minutes Go for the high score.” Pretty self-explanatory. Try to survive for 5 minutes against a looot of enemies.

Deathmatch

3-minute mayhem, 2 to 4 players. This is actually much more fun than it sounds. You start in a relatively small room but massive explosions alter the size and the shape of the room making it bigger. You fight for survival and weapon drops. Player with most kills wins. This is a perfect party mode. You definitely want to play this with friends (you can play with bots as well).


Pros:
Nice pixel graphics and great chiptune music (seriously, music is good).
Hundreds of different weapons, mods and upgrades.
A lot of different enemies (not just zombies) and unique looking environments.
RPG elements (leveling, stats). You level up during a playthrough but also earn coins to improve your character’s stats permanently.
Addicting gameplay with a lot of replay value.
Pets that you can find or buy. They will fight and level up alongside you.
Online and local co-op / deathmatch to play with friends and a full controller support.
Cons?
I am surprised to say there aren’t many. I haven’t encountered any major issues so I am just nitpicking here to be honest:
My only major complaint is that the game only run at 30 FPS and with so much action and movement going on it could really use 60. Vsync helps eliminate screen tearing.
Depending on the background, text can be impossible to read. Fonts are bulky and awkward looking in general. Inventory window is tiny.
I would really love if this game had Steam achievements. According to the developer they are coming in one of the future updates so it’s not a big deal.
Bottom line: This feels like a solid complete game, not an early access title. It is fun to play. I have not noticed any major glitches. There is more than enough content as it is to keep you entertained and there are more updates on the way.
If you are remotely interested in this type of games, don’t skip Zombie Party. Well-deserved thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've never been much for Zombie games, and I'm also no good at parties.  But, with a responsive dev willing to try new things and listen to concerns, Zombie Party is an early access game worth watching.

With this game, you can expect a colorful top-down arena-based shooter with charming pixel graphics.  There are several game modes, but you will primarily be fighting off hordes of enemies that arrive in waves with a boss fight here and there.

The thing I like most about Zombie Party is the weapon system.  At any given time, your character will be armed with a pistol, a shotgun, an SMG, an assault rifle, and a launcher.  Each of these weapons can be extensively customized with many combinations of attribute-altering artifacts, meaning that the same weapon, depending on how you build it, could produce rapid-firing spreadshot lasers that ricochet from enemy to enemy, or large piercing incendiary spears that ignite whole clusters of enemies at once, or any number of other things.  When you’ve earned some cash, you can buy improved versions of your older weapons, adding even more customization.

Occasionally, a vanquished enemy will drop a supergun, a powerful weapon that disappears when the limited clip is empty.  These are not necessary to use, and are in some cases not as strong as the combinations you’ve Frankensteined together, but can be really fun; you’ll get things like the Flamewaller, the Teddy Launcher, and the Spiderbot Cannon, which all produce unique effects.

There’s also a neat magic system; enemies drop spells that have randomized type, damage, range, elemental attribute, and cooldown that can be swapped around and serve as a secondary attack.

I’ve spent about 10 hours with this game.  It’s still early access at my time of writing this, and so far, I’ve found a few issues.

One; it’s a bit too easy.  Enemies spawn in little groups around the arena but quickly end up clustering in the center.  By strafing and jumping in a wide circle, you’ll basically never die.  Additionally, by putting your best customizations on your character’s pistol or pistol-equivalent (the only weapon with unlimited ammo), you can mop up creatures indefinitely without ever swapping your weapons around.  At this point, I never feel threatened in the adventure mode, and as there’s currently no way to save progress on your run, I end up quitting.

Two; it’s a bit grindy.  There’s a ton of unlockables that all require lots of coin; and you can also spend coin to permanently increase the stats of your favorite characters.  It would take a lot of playing to max everything.  I never have incentive to buy weapon upgrades (which are temporary), because I need that money for the permanent stuff.

Despite the issues, this game is fun to dip into.  I recommend it in its current state, and feel it may improve as the work continues.

==== Should You Buy This Game? ====Zombie Party is a twin-stick shooting rogue-lite with RPG elements containing a lot of content for an early access game. There are currently 4 unique game modes (Adventure, Dungeon, Arcade, Deathmatch) to test your skill along with online leaderboards. Even though the game is in an alpha state at the moment, I can definitely recommend this game to fans of the twin-stick shooter genre, especially those that want to take part in the developing process with continued feedback. In the following review, I will only be commenting on its first impressions and the current state of the game.

==== First Impressions ====----05/20/2016----
Adventure Mode
When you first choose a character, you will have a few customizable options to choose such as specific weapons for each gun type. After starting, waves of enemies will spawn with breaks in between to give yourself time to level up your stats, change items, or purchase items from the shop. Although most enemies are consituents of a mindless horde, some are tanky while others will utilize special abilities/weapons. Beating a boss will progress the story to the next area. It's important to note that you can also pickup single-use items or magics that you can repeatedly use as long as you have sufficient mana.

Dungeon Mode
This mode is a dungeon-crawler with a boss at the end of each dungeon. Unlike Adventure mode, this mode allows you to play at a much slower pace. The dungeons are procedurally generated and present drastically different biomes. For both all modes, ammo and gold are randomly awarded upon killing enemies, or picked up throughout the area. Although I preferred playing this mode the most, I really would have liked to see complex puzzles or mechanics.

Arcade Mode
If you want to play a score-attack/survival mode that sends 10,000 enemies your way for you to defeat in 5 minutes, then here you go.

Deathmatch Mode
Just like it sounds, Deathmatch mode allows you to play against friends via local coop or AI bots in a small arena with unlimited ammo. The objective is to get the most kills.

==== Current State of the Game ====The developers have shown continued interest in the game, as seen by their posts in the Discussions board along with monthly updates. I haven't ran into any game-breaking bugs as of yet, and the game seems to contain most of its desired core contents. The biggest takeaway points are listed below:

Pros:4 unique game modes
Diverse dungeons/environments/enemies/bosses
Procedural generation
Addicting & fun
Mini-map & location highlighter
Cons:Gold gain is too slow in the beginning
Some particle effects are too large
Particles sometimes blend into the environment too much
Weak graphics
==== Early Access ====For those that are not aware of the Early Access concept, it is perfectly acceptable for bugs to be present and game mechanics to be missing (especially at the alpha stage of development). With that in mind, I can at least say that I have enjoyed what I've played so far, and hope to see more people get a jump on Zombie Party.

Zombie Party is a Top-down, twin stick, retro, RPG, bullet-hell zombie shooter for up to 4 players.
It contains four different modes
Adventure Mode: Survive lots of waves of a zombie horde, with a help of a shop and plenty of guns, and defeat a boss at the end of the stage to advance
Arcade Mode: No shop, no help. No escape. Survive against a giant wave of 10,000 Enemies, with only you and your partners
Dungeon Mode: Explore a generated dungeon, with many floors to explore, shooting the mushrooms and slimes as you progress
Deathmatch: Pins you and your friends (or bots, if you don’t have friends) in a small level and start killing each other PVP style, with the map slowly expanding as you blow up more of it.

+ An absolute Tonne of weapons, ranging from your average AK-47, to a RAINBOWTHROWER THAT SHOOTS TEDDY BEARS. Some weapons are absolutely insane, such as the Rocket-machinegun, or even the regular shotgun.

+The game is a good challenge, especially the boss fights, and feels satisfying when you win
+Bright and colourful (almost needs a seizure warning, IMO), fun and fast paced
+Playing with bots makes the game a lot easier than just playing by your-self.
Cons:
+Can get a bit repetitive.
+Currently no online matchmaking, at time of review
+Bosses can be pretty difficult, so maybe the health should be a bit lower

All in all Zombie party is a very fun game, great for wasting some time on.

Zombie Party is a delightful little mash up. The game is early access and is likely to change considerably. But it's so much fun even at this early stage.

For an early access game Zombie Party has a surprizing amount of content; there are numerous game modes in single player as well as coop multiplayer and Deathmatch pvp. Unfortunately the coop is a little laggy and choppy right now, but the single player and the DM are very enjoyable.

At first glance the game might seem like a Nuclear Throne type of game, but Zombie Party has much more in common with a hack & slash than even a rogue-lite, never mind rogue-like. That is not a criticism of the game; but for clarity's sake, I do not feel the game plays as a rogue-like. Zombie Party is very liberal with its drops, players get tons of weapon drops from almost any mob, lots of HP drops, and a truck load of ammo. So the game wants the players to just go ham, nonstop. I am all for a bullet flued rampage.

The game modes available in the game right now are: Dungeon mode, a level based progression through different locations with a boss at the end of each chapter. An arcade mode in which the player needs to kill a minimum number of mobs. A survival mode, where the player goes through different areas in the game facing waves of mobs. And a Deathmatch game with 3 players in a small room trying their best to off one another. Survival, Arcade and Dungeon modes can be played coop; although we need some game fixed before they run smoothly. There are considerable frame drops and freezes in coop. As single player games go survival is my favourite, in Zombie Party that game mode is called Adventure, and the player faces down waves of mobs and attempts to keep them in check. For Dungeon mode, I just didn't feel enough of a reward to my runs, didn't know why I needed to go further. I felt the overwhelming hordes in Adventure and Arcade were more my thing.

The gameplay is fairly straight forward. The player starts out by picking the character they'd like to run with, they have some different base stats, those stats can be upgraded when leveling in the run. Review
Zombie Party is an extremely addictive action shooter that isnt really about zombies as much as it is about blasting random hordes of enemies with a really large variety of guns!

The game has several modes from a time travelling adventure to online multiplayer. The pixely graphics are cute, and the music is nice, but what really makes it stand out from similar titles is the level of customization. There are 34 characters available at the moment, though a lot of them need to be unlocked with coins you pick up as you play. The basic characters start with a default set of weapons, and slightly different attributes while some characters you unlock will have different attribute variations and some weapons unique to them. You can also use coins to increase a characters starting attributes, or better starting weapons and you can even buy hats! The game has a pet system which has cute animals follow you around giving you a hand. I have only found one pet, and he helps by picking up loot and bringing it to me.

As you play you earn experience to level up and each level earns you a new skill point which can be used to boost your attributes(for the current game only) I cant even begin to list the number of items you can loot. There are potions, grenades, magic runes that let you cast spells, even melee weapons like a giant hammer or a chainsaw. There are also artifacts and weapon mods. Artifacts changes the projectile of the weapon they are attached to, and the mods have several different effects, such as upping the weapons damage, making its projectiles larger, faster or even splitting them.

There are a variety of different enemies, and several bosses with some interesting abilities to make your life difficult >:D

Over all, this is a great game. I recommend getting it, even if you're not usually a fan of this kind of game (I'm not) I have had a LOT of fun with it, and I know I will play this one for many more hours.

Zombie Party is mental. There's so much going on it can be easy to lose track of your character. Under all the mayhem there's actually quite a lot of depth. There's a massive variety in weapons, and the base weapons can be modded to produce a great variety of effects. There are also many abilities available. The mods and abilities drop as you play the game, which makes every game different.

Each time you play you start off by selecting a character, and it's not just a case of choosing the model you like the look of as each character starts off with different stats. These stats can be improved as you play, so you can steer your character the right way according to what items are dropping for you.

There are a few different game modes, and whilst the gameplay is all the same it does help to have the variety. That mixed with the millions of combinations that come from the items that drop and a whole bunch of characters to choose from really makes every game a fresh experience.

Zombie party might look a little simple and underwhelming, but don't let that put you off. Underneath it's a deep, enjoyable experience, with an addictive just-one-more-game feel to it.

Adventure: It is a fast-paced battle in an arena where you fight waves of enemies in a restricted area.
Dungeon: It is a mode that gives you more freedom to walk, explore and battle at your own pace.
Arcade: Try to kill 10k enemies as fast as possible
Deathmatch: PVP mode to play against your friends.

There is also a shop keeper that appears between each waves to let you buy ammunitions, food and weapons to help you survive as long as possible. Zombie Party is one of those games that brings you back to your childhood with its retro art style and classic snes music. It's a top down arcade shooter game with a plenty of character customization and a lot of weapon variations. The game is very easy, but as you progress later on, it becomes more essential to learn how to upgrade your character and weapons to beat mobs and bosses.

Graphics:
Visually, the Zombie Party is very appealing and very reminiscent of the old rpg games. The characters move fluidly but a bit lacking in animation. The game runs at 30fps, which is great, but playing at 60fps will make the game run more fluidly.

Gameplay:
Very simple premise, shoot zombies, loot weapons, upgrade your weapons/character, then shoot more zombies! But what makes this different from other top down shooter game is its variety and the roguelike element.

Music and Sound:
The music is fun and entertaining, it'll keep you in your toes while killing a ton of zombies. The sound however is a bit annoying. Most of the sound effects are dull and there are sounds that will really hurt your ears.

Review
Fun and varied with a surprising amount of depth.

At its heart it's a wave-based shooter. Adventure mode has you take on waves of enemies before fighting a boss and moving onto the next area. Dungeon mode is less hectic and does away with the waves, instead having you descend random dungeon levels (with destructible walls!) until you get down to the boss. Enemies get tougher as you progress, but you level up along the way and can assign earned skill points to make yourself stronger, tougher, and faster as you see fit. You also collect gold which is spent between waves at the shop on new weapons or ammo and supplies. After you die the game tallies up the gold you collected and adds it to a running total, which you can use to permanently upgrade your character's starting stats or weapons so you'll do better next time.

The waves of enemies are massive, which makes it all the more satisfying when you tear through them en-masse with a powerful special weapon or a decked out shotgun or grenade launcher. A really nice touch is that each area has its own matching set of enemies (e.g. jellyfish in the underwater area). Further switching things up, the bosses have unique attacks with bullet hell like patterns instead of simply being an oversized enemy.

Where things get really get interesting is its weapon system. There's tons of disposable special weapons you can find as drops and you'll never know quite what they'll do until you try them. Your mainstays are five basics weapon types (pistol / SMG / shotgun / rifle / grenade launcher), and those each have three mod slots and an artifact slot (except the pistol). As you plow down enemies you'll find mods that range from simple accuracy/damage/fire rate boosts to ones that affect the projectiles themselves, like homing" which makes them gravitate towards enemies.

It felt like I was cheating when I first used a spread mod on the grenade launcher to make it 3 grenades per shot

Short Version

A simple concept greatly enhanced with oodles of variety and replay value, Zombie Party is an enjoyable single and multi-player twin-stick shooter if you're looking for a game that focuses on the fun factor without wasting time on telling a story.

New modes and updates have been consistently added to date. At the time of writing we have:
Adventure: Defeat waves of enemies, shop for upgrades in between then defeat the challenging and inventive boss and move on to a totally new world with new enemies and attack patterns.
Arcade: Reach 10,000 zombie kills as quickly as possible. No upgrades or stopping to shop, just keep shooting and aim for a high score!
Dungeon: Great mode with a lot of replay value. Travel through larger maps of randomized dungeons with new enemies and scenery. Bosses make appearances too.
Deathmatch: A barebones deathmatch mode for 2-4 players. Shoot each other in tiny arenas. Probably won't grab your attention for more than a few minutes.
A.I bots make a great addition to solo or local co-op games. Let them tag along in any of the game modes above and they will collect and upgrade weapons and hardly ever let go of the trigger. They will even revive you if you're downed. Adding bots in is also a good way to see what super weapons the unlockable characers have, without spending gold to unlock them first. Excess gold can also be spend on permanent stat upgrades or hats (woohoo!) for your favourite characters.

The number of weapon upgrades and visual variety of their projectiles is huge. They can be upgraded to increasingly ridiculous versions, for example the shotgun can become a blunderbuss or a fish launcher (more like giant dolphin launcher). On top of this, artifacts modify the projectile type e,g bullets become lasers and runes (auto-equipped to a max of 3 and interchable) can add elemental effects. Weapons also upgrade in level as you use them. The result is a game screen constantly filled with rapidly-changing bombs, spinning lasers, auto-turrets, exploding teddy bears and so much more.

At it's core, Zombie Party a simple wave-based twin-stick shooter with enough variety to keep 1-4 players occupied for quite a few hours.

Review
Zombie Party is a neat little pixel-style arena-based game. There are a number of different gamemodes, but they all have similar concepts - kill the enemies and progress to the next stage. The game has an active developer within the community and updates are frequent. It is colourful and the huge range of weapons and customisation and weapon modding options allow the game to keep your attention for quite a while. The cute graphics are simple but appealing, although in some areas they are a little too simple. But overall, its a fun little game.

The game is of course still in Early Access, so some aspects of the game are still a little under-developed. For example, the AI is very simple - enemies basically just walk straight towards you. Also, the enemies and bosses dont vary very much from zone to zone, having extremely similar abilities and actions (but of course different appearances). However, I am sure these flaws will be worked on in future updates.

I will now briefly describe the current gamemodes:

Adventure mode puts you against waves of enemies. After 5 waves, you fight the boss of that zone then progress to the next zone. The shop and dropped weapons and artifacts allow a huge amount of customisation. I'm not too sure about what happens at the end of adventure mode (if there is an end) because I'm not amazing at the game and have only managed to get to Zone 3.

Dungeon mode allows you to fight your way through the different dungeon floors. I've not played too much of this mode, but there is a large boss fight planned at the end of this dungeon-crawling mode.

In arcade mode you attempt to kill 10,000 enemies in 5 minutes, which to me seems absolutely impossible. But I'm sure if you're good at the game this could offer a considerable challenge.

And finally, deathmatch mode lets you fight either a friend or a bot, 1v1. This allows you to fight enemies with identical abilities and similar strategies to you, making an even match, instead of fighting hordes of mindless zombies.

Rating:
7.5/10

The cute pixel graphics make the game very aesthetically appealing.
Good controller support.
A variety of different gamemodes, keeping your interest for longer.
Online and local multiplayer support, as well as steam leaderboards.
Frequent updates and an active developer.
Cons:Very simple AI.
The game gets a little repetitive after a while.
Clicking Pet Sanctuary in the main menu when you have not unlocked pets crashes the game.

Early Access Review

Zombie Party. What a great game with lots of potential, but just like all early access games, it still needs some work. This game reminds me of some of the early childhood arcade games I used to play, and I can’t stop playing it simply because of that. Although I do enjoy this game, there are a few things it lacks, but like many people say… Perfect is impossible.
The game gives you a wide range of weapons which also comes along with endless upgrading possibilities, not only for your weapons but your character’s stats as well. This leaves for numerous different ways to take on the game. Gold is the currency in the game and is used to buy upgrades for guns and weapons as well as special outfits for your characters. There are also multiple different characters which keeps you interested in the game even if you max out one character’s stats.
As for the graphics and the sound effects, I really love the 8-bit feel to the game’s visual and sounds. The graphics give out the feel of a 80s game and the colors blend very well together.
The production of the music is excellent but should be more fitting to the scenery. It is very weird walking through a mushroom forest with castle-like music playing in the background. The music could have also had more of an 8-bit feel just to add the nostalgia the developers seem to be going for.
The bosses in adventure mode were super fun all the way through, and the fact that they each have their own special abilities will keep you on your toes. I definitely recommend getting a second player on with you, whether it’s a friend or a bot, because the bosses get super challenging very early in the game. Although the bosses were super cool in adventure mode, which encouraged me to play more, wondering what the next boss would be, the whole thing lacked a story line and there was no character lore (such as their background, what they are fighting for, etc.). The procedural idea behind dungeon mode gave it more of an adventure feel than adventure mode itself.
Deathmatch was super fun for the classic arcade game fans and the people who like to kill zombies and bugs aimlessly with no goal other than surviving. The only thing that Deathmatch is missing is the online multiplayer which I feel like, if integrated, could generate more interest in the game as well as giving it much more potential to be extremely successful.
All in all, Zombie Party was pretty fun but still has some ways to go. It is only in its early access stages and I have lots of confidence in the developers of this game. The wide range of weapon and character upgrades as well as the nostalgic feel is what makes this game. If they worked more in adding a story line I feel like this game would improve greatly. Integrating multiplayer would also be a great idea since multiplayer gaming has almost taken over the industry. I look forward to seeing what this game will bring us in the future.  Zombie Party is ranked 7/10 for me, and I recommend you check it out for yourself!

Zombie Party is one of those games that is going to surprise you. I didn't think I was going to like it even as I was typing the CVV code in for the purchase, but I love supporting indie, and I was at least very curious. I've only spent thirty dollars on it, but already it's made my list of games to bring out when I want to to play with someone in the same room as me.

First, the Good: This game is beautifully addictive. The gameplay is simple enough that you'll be decently proficient in very little time, but deep enough to be interesting after a couple of plays. The weapon customization was oddly engaging, once you realize it's there, and substantially adds to the replay value. The game maintains a high tension level throughout the game, so it has a high multiplayer/spectacle value.

The bad: Honestly, there's not much bad I can say about this game aside from two glaring issues. First, I'm not sure how well shopping and skills work in multiplayer, as well as weapon switching, but I haven't tried it yet, so I don't know. The one I DO know about, though, is the lack of progression. With progression goals (maybe unlocking new special weapons?), the game would give people a reason to keep coming back. It would also add to the game's somewhat lacking content, though I still found it incredibly fun to play.

In any case, This game (AS IS, EVEN) is worth the eight dollars, and is only going to get better as development continues.

This recommendation comes with a massive caveat:

I can't *really* recommend this, but I don't think it's a bad game for the price point of 4 bucks and the fact that this game isn't really in my wheelhouse makes me feel dirty for giving this a thumbs down.  I'm not a lover of twinstick shooters, but I do like the genre.  However, this one didn't really win me over for a few reasons.

It's overly-chaotic.  The colors and flashing get old really quick for me and at times it's hard to even tell what the hell is going on in all the chaos.  The sound design lends to this chaos in certain situations, and can become overbearing.  Some people may enjoy the chaos, I found it frustrating.

The goal is disappointing.  Now, I don't really know how far the main mode goes, but I honestly just got bored and killed myself before getting to the end.  All you do is run in circles and fire on a blob of enemies til it does, occasionally picking up a new gun or powerup to make the job easier.  This leads me to my next point:

The enemies are just tanky bullet-sponges with no sophistication.  Occasionally an enemy may fire a projectile or something, but as you circle around the level, they just huddle up in the middle of your circle like you're the moon to the planet created by these creatures.  From there you just keep running in circles, firing into the blob until the wave is complete, and repeat.

To me, it feels like the Dynasty Warriors of shoot-em-ups.  Some people like Dynasty Warriors, and if you do you might really like this game for what it is and that is okay.  I, however, do not enjoy Dynasty Warriors and did not enjoy this game.

This game is insane. In a good way, though. Then I found out it was made using GameMaker: Studio, and I was even more impressed. Zombie Party is a game about killing, well, zombies...and other enemies. The main objective in the game is to kill everything. There isn't really any strategy involved. It's a game to pick up every now and then if you have a few minutes to spare. It feels like it could be played on mobile devices without much difficulty.

There isn't really a tutorial, but the controls are displayed to you at the beginning of every match. The sounds are great, if not a little overwhelming at times, such as when everyone is firing an advanced weapon at the same time or picking up coins/ammunition/items.  The music gives it a kind of retro" feel.

There are four gamemodes in Zombie Party: Adventure
recommended:
Arcade and Deathmatch. A-D-A-D. A dad. This game is/will be the father of the zombie apocalypse.

*cough*

Adventure doesn't really live up to its name. You try to survive through as many waves of enemies as possible
hoursPlayed: buying new weapons from the store and collecting others from dead zombies. There isn't really any incentive to actually "explore
voteText:
and there are so many enemies that walking around too much is pretty difficult.

Dungeon is my personal favorite gamemode; it's just like an RPG! Well, minus the quests. You explore each floor and once you've killed enough enemies, you can descend to the next floor. There are chests with items, abilities, spells and stat points that you can use to your advantage, and there are many secrets to discover as well.

Arcade is probably the most insane gamemode of the four. You race to beat the clock and kill 10,000 enemies within five minutes! As you can imagine, the gunfire and enemies are crazy. This is when you may notice the game's only real drawback - when the firing rates get too high and there are so many enemies, you can easily lose track of where your crosshair and character are located. Because of this, I would occasionally find myself aimlessly firing in a random direction, not hitting any enemies, and losing health. After a while this can get pretty frustrating. However, I still liked the frenzy.

Deathmatch is my least favorite of the four, perhaps because I don't have any friends. The idea behind this gamemode is to kill each other, or in my case, kill the bots while they try to kill you. You're in a limited area which gives weapons with a wide range of fire an advantage.

Overall, I do recommend this game - but not for the full price. $8 times a tad pricey for something as repetitive as this. Each round is virtually the same. So I would only recommend it at least 40% off.

General Review
This is an Early Access Game which is going through its Alpha 8.0 update at the moment of this review, i may change it if i feel to do so and changes made are worth a new review

You can clearly see it is a 2D top-down shooter which also mixes some RPG elements like the stats management system for your character, weapon boost packs which increase their stats(damage, firerate, etc) and secondary magic powers which require mana(which refills by itself). You, as a member of a team of(maximum) four players must complete a time travel quest where you fight against different kind of enemies through different areas and well designed levels. There are also another three gamemodes: Dungeon(where you must complete different floors, clearing them out of enemies and finding the exit to progress through levels), Survival(name says it all, you must survive and kill 10,000 zombies in less than 5 minutes, you have access to all kind of weapons but you are still vulnerable so keep that in mind), and in the end but not less important we have Deathmatch gamemode(name says it all, PvP non stop action, the one that gets most kills in a round of, i think, 5 minutes wins).


Graphics and Physics
Graphics are decent despite it is a 2D top-down shooter. There are so many nice effects added for guns and enemies. Physics are well worked, you dont fall off map or get stuck in any area(atleast it didnt happened to me, but who knows). HUD and User Interface is very well done, you can see where you have to go through menus and your inventory you can clearly see where you have to go to in your inventory, stats management menu, etc.
Graphics and physics are very well designed, you can hardly find something that breaks the gameplay like errors and things like that.

Sounds
This may, and may not be its strongest point. It depends on the player... It has a good soundtrack list(for me), it fits perfectly with this retro RPG Top down monsters shooter. But, it can always get better.
It should have some kind of hyped music when facing bosses or when going through secret areas(Dungeon Gamemode), that can make the player feel even more interested in knowing whats going to happen next. But anyways, music is good and sounds are good too, but in my personal view i would like it to have some kind of difference between facing normal enemies and facing bosses.

Gameplay

Developer did a great work doing a(maximum) four players local coop, game deserves it and it was a mandatory thing to do.(I played it with friends and we loved it).
Online multiplayer will also be implemented as developer says, which it will increase the fun alot more(because people that dont have alot of friends or controllers can also feel the cooperative part of the game).
Controls feel very good, quick and fast. There are alot of options regarding camera distance view, thats something great.


Final Review
I dont find anything that i can hardly punish from this game, i liked every aspect of this one graphics, physics, gameplay, everything fits perfect for this game. But what i should say that it is doing an EXCEPTIONAL work, its the developing team. They are doing a great work, launching new updates almost every month(check changelogs and announcements).
Im proud to say this is a MUST have game, because it will have a great online community, developers are working hard to make the game better accepting suggestions and because its a very fun top-down shooter!

Zombie Party is a Twin Stick Shooter with pixel graphics and a lot of RPG elements. Now what makes it special? Well I'm glad you asked so let me tell you:

First off, I am not too fond of games with pixel graphics as I find them to be flooding the Steam Store. What makes this one different however is the mixture of simple pixel art and great looking sprites, i.e. for weapon projectiles, etc.

Also, the most important part: This is Early Access done right. You can't feel that the game is in its EA state but rather a pretty muched finished version. I've had no crashes or issues whatsoever. The main reason the devs seem to be doing EA is because they want to listen to feedback and improve their game like the player would love to see it. That's something you rarely encounter these days, so big ups for that.

To get back to the game itself, the controls are smooth and the movement in the arenas is always fluid. Come to think of it, it's not only arenas. There's also PVP and a dungeon mode with bosses and stuff. And you can keep collected gold after a game session to purchase hats (Yay!) or even better, character models. There's even Mr Skeltal. So if you're looking for good calcium, purchase this game!

Now you might be wondering what I do NOT like about this game? Well let me tell you. Since it's EA I hope the devs will fix these issues at some point:

- There is no true widescreen mode - you have 2 black bars like in an emulated 4:3 mode.
- The camera does often zoom out way too late if you play with multiple players (Or bots).
- The FOV is too low. Enemies can easily sneak up on you.
- Sometimes the effects are a tad too much and you lose track of what's going on on the screen.
- Weapon upgrades are too expensive if you ask me. You can barely afford 2 within one complete wave.
- The special powers activated with LT is a little confusing as well at the moment.

Other than that I think this is a great title with great potential!

Zombie Party is a Twin Stick Shooter with pixel graphics and a lot of RPG elements. Now what makes it special? Well I'm glad you asked so let me tell you:

First off, I am not too fond of games with pixel graphics as I find them to be flooding the Steam Store. What makes this one different however is the mixture of simple pixel art and great looking sprites, i.e. for weapon projectiles, etc.

Also, the most important part: This is Early Access done right. You can't feel that the game is in its EA state but rather a pretty muched finished version. I've had no crashes or issues whatsoever. The main reason the devs seem to be doing EA is because they want to listen to feedback and improve their game like the player would love to see it. That's something you rarely encounter these days, so big ups for that.

To get back to the game itself, the controls are smooth and the movement in the arenas is always fluid. Come to think of it, it's not only arenas. There's also PVP and a dungeon mode with bosses and stuff. And you can keep collected gold after a game session to purchase hats (Yay!) or even better, character models. There's even Mr Skeltal. So if you're looking for good calcium, purchase this game!

Now you might be wondering what I do NOT like about this game? Well let me tell you. Since it's EA I hope the devs will fix these issues at some point:

- There is no true widescreen mode - you have 2 black bars like in an emulated 4:3 mode.
- The camera does often zoom out way too late if you play with multiple players (Or bots).
- The FOV is too low. Enemies can easily sneak up on you.
- Sometimes the effects are a tad too much and you lose track of what's going on on the screen.
- Weapon upgrades are too expensive if you ask me. You can barely afford 2 within one complete wave.
- The special powers activated with LT is a little confusing as well at the moment.

Other than that I think this is a great title with great potential!

This is an EARLY ACCESS REVIEW!This game was given to me by the publisher for the sake of [providing development feedback[/b]. However, this review remains impartial and based entirely on the game itself.[/i]

What's the game?Zombie Party is a bullet hell, emphasis on hell (and bullet).. The game has a multiplayer arena that I haven't used since I have no friends, an adventure mode that you can do solo or with a team that I will never have because I have no friends, and a dungeon mode that you can... I'll leave it at that.

What features are in it?ANY GAME IN WHICH YOU CAN DECIMATE FUCCBOIS AS MR. SKELTAL WITH A BONE BLASTER IS WORTH PLAYING.
To start, you must pick a character. Your saved up coins, once you don't use to buy guns before you die, can be used to buy new characters. Each has different stat boosts.

In Adventure mode, you go into a huge arena and shoot the bazillions of monsters that slowly trudge towards you.
You then get blasted with a billion lasers and die to a boss, no matter how prepared you are for it.
You can buy different guns with different base stats with coins that oft drop from monsters.
Also dropping are several things like special guns, enchantments, and boosts. You can use 3 buffs and 1 other enchantment on each gun, and they can make devastating combinations based on the firing pattern of the gun itself.

In Dungeon mode, you run through different floors full of monsters, explosives, traps, and boxes. Boxes and monsters can drop coins and monsters, and you don't get totally overrun like you do in Adventure mode. It's very similar, and quite fun. Sometimes, monsters glitch out of the map and you glitch in between a crystal and a wall and have to restart. Checkpoints would be nice, so would not glitching.

Why should you buy this game? This game is a bullet hell. That's quite fun.
It has a lot of variety.
It's a very fast-paced game in 2 dimensions.
You can play as Mr. Skeltal.
There is a lot of intuition that goes into maximizing damage in specific situations.
There are multiple game modes.
This is where I'd put my games with friends... IF I HAD ANY!

What's the catch?Some of it just feels imba.
The bosses are less intuitive and more damage cannons.
You can't skip your character barfing up a few hundred coins after you die.
You can get stuck and have to restart.
You can use fire guns underwater.
You can use fire guns in space.
Some traps have no signs at all, no way to avoid them.
Jumping is a bit slow and unvariable.
It's early access - we have no idea where it's gonna go.
Sprites are pretty ugly.

OverallYou should buy it. It's reasonably priced for what it is. It's early access, so there's a lot of room for growth. May get reworks on stuff like sprites.
Though without a story, it includes all of the good elements of a bullet hell game. Totally worth $8.

Zombie Party.  If you've always wanted a gun that shoots rainbows, mindlessly shoot shrooms so you can collect their dead bodies in order to pay off your car loan and the loan shark you got the loan from, you can do all those things... hopefully not that you got a loan shark.  Don't do that.  That's a no no.

But Zombie Party is the playful Rouge-lite that isn't too serious, but serious enough that the devs are wonderful and make ACTUAL updates that benefit how the game plays.

From the gun mods that allow you to modify your guns on the fly to the pet system that makes your cat act like a Fallout 4 HalluciGen nightmare, the game has tight controls, pretty sweet gunplay, upgradeable characters via - GASP - CURRENCY YOU EARN THROUGH DUNGEONS, it's all the free game minus the cost of the game.  It's pretty damn sweet.

I'll keep it short, but here are the positives:

+ Gunplay is varied via modded weapons, different weapon types, buy different weapons (through earning currency to spend on perma-upgrades or buying them from a vendor in-game), SUPERGUNS (anyone want a taste of the ♥♥♥♥ing rainbow?  GIVE IT TO THEM)
+ many different characters to unlock and upgrade!
+ PETS - ON - LSD
+ Sound design is good!
+ Every map is procedurally generated, but environments remain the same per dungeon set (like dungeon 1 is a forest, 2 is a literal dungeon, 3 is a desert, etc.)
+ Kind of adorable graphics (go with me here)
+ Not overly serious and is fun to waste hours on
+ HATS

Negatives:
- Sometimes can get stuck in the enviornment but that's a bug that's likely to get fixed
- Upgrades only go /so/ far in its current state but you'll end up spending lots of time upgrading characters and unlocking them as you go

Zombie apocalypse/10: would endorse mass genocide to buy a hat again.
